citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, the facility representative could not substantiate the last time the Attending Veterinarian,
(AV), had visited the facility. The inspector contacted the AV and in a telephone conversation with the AV on 3/11/2025,
the AV stated that it had been several years since he visited the exhibitor's facility since the animals needing treatment
were brought to his veterinary office.
Regularly scheduled visits are important because they allow the AV to observe the health, husbandry, food/diets, pest
control, etc., and to make professional recommendations to enhance the health and welfare of the animals and how they
are kept.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor.
Correct by April 30, 2025, and forward

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, Gypsy, a female Blue-and-Gold Macaw was observed to have feather loss on her breast,
legs, and underwing area. She also has an overgrown beak. The facility representative said that she has had this feather
loss since they rescued her (approximately 10 years ago). The licensee had not contacted the AV about the bird and its
behavioral and physical conditions. When the AV was asked about this macaw in a telephone conversation on 3/11/2025,
the AV stated that he was "not aware of its condition and had not seen it."
It is important that daily observations are communicated to the AV so that the AV has the authority and means to examine
and treat conditions that are affecting the animal's health and behavior to provide adequate veterinary care.
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of
animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
Correct by 3/17/2025 and forward

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, it could not be substantiated that the AV had approved the written plan of environmental
enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the licensee's birds. The inspector contacted the AV in a
telephone conversation on 3/11/2025 and asked if the AV had approved it and he stated that he had not.
This is important because AV must have appropriate authority to oversee the adequacy of all aspects of animal care and
use to optimize the health and psychological well-being of the birds.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides.
Correct by March 31, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of the inspection, the facility representative could not substantiate the last time the Attending Veterinarian, 
(AV), had visited the facility. The inspector contacted the AV and in a telephone conversation with the AV on 3/11/2025, 
the AV stated that it had been several years since he visited the exhibitor's facility since the animals needing treatment 
were brought to his veterinary office.  
 
Regularly scheduled visits are important because they allow the AV to observe the health, husbandry, food/diets, pest 
control, etc., and to make professional recommendations to enhance the health and welfare of the animals and how they 
are kept.  
 
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time 
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary 
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor. 
 
Correct by April 30, 2025, and forward 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of the inspection, Gypsy, a female Blue-and-Gold Macaw was observed to have feather loss on her breast, 
legs, and underwing area. She also has an overgrown beak. The facility representative said that she has had this feather 
loss since they rescued her (approximately 10 years ago). The licensee had not contacted the AV about the bird and its 
behavioral and physical conditions. When the AV was asked about this macaw in a telephone conversation on 3/11/2025, 
the AV stated that he was "not aware of its condition and had not seen it."  
 
It is important that daily observations are communicated to the AV so that the AV has the authority and means to examine 
and treat conditions that are affecting the animal's health and behavior to provide adequate veterinary care. 
 
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being; Provided, however, That daily observation of 
animals may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian; and Provided, further, That a

mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of 
animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian. 
 
Correct by 3/17/2025 and forward 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of the inspection, it could not be substantiated that the AV had approved the written plan of environmental 
enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the licensee's birds. The inspector contacted the AV in a 
telephone conversation on 3/11/2025 and asked if the AV had approved it and he stated that he had not. 
 
This is important because AV must have appropriate authority to oversee the adequacy of all aspects of animal care and 
use to optimize the health and psychological well-being of the birds. 
 
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for 
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the 
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted 
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. 
 
Correct by March 31, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIGEON INCLUDING ALL DOMESTIC BREEDS
